'''Harmonica Hinds''' (born January 4, 1945) moved from his birthplace in [[Trinidad]] to [[Canada]] and then settled permanently in [[Chicago]].  He was influenced by blues musicians and started playing harmonica at an early age.  He became known in the 1970s when he played on the house band of the famed Theresa's Lounge in Chicago.  He shared the stage and played on albums of many great blues artists for more than five decades.  He made his first recording in 2008 followed by recordings in 2010 and 2012.  He is considered one of the most talented Chicago blues musicians and he remains active on the Chicago blues scene.

== Life and career ==

Mervyn G.H. Hinds, born January 4, 1945 in Trinidad ,moved from his birthplace to [[Ottawa]], Canada, and then to [[Toronto]].<ref name="Regional"/><ref name="BG Hinds">{{cite web|url=http://bg.buddyguy.com/harmonica-hinds/|title=Harmonica Hinds|author=Mark Augustine|date= April 25, 2013|website=|publisher= Buddy Guy's Legends (Checkerboard Productions)|accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> He moved to Chicago in 1977 and then to [[New Orleans]] from 1976 to 1983, and then permanently back to Chicago.<ref name="Regional"/>  Hinds was first captivated with blues harmonica while in Canada when he saw [[Sonny Terry]] play.  He started playing the harmonica from age 7 to 9.  He started singing the blues in 1968.<ref name="BG Hinds"/>  He received his first music lesson on the street from [[Lafayette Leake]] while living in Toronto.  When he was studying sociology at [[Carleton University]] in Ottawa, [[James Cotton]] invited him to Chicago.  He was also encouraged by New Orleans musicians David Lastie and [[George Porter]].<ref name="BG Hinds"/>

Hinds became known in the 1970s when he played on the house band of the famed Theresa's Lounge in Chicago, often sharing the stage with [[Junior Wells]].<ref name="Something Else">{{cite web|url=http://somethingelsereviews.com/2012/04/24/harmonica-hinds-if-speed-was-just-a-thought-2012/|title=Is Speed Was Just a Thought|author=Nick DeRiso|date= 2012|website=http://somethingelsereviews.com/|publisher=Something Else!|accessdate=October 28, 2013}}</ref> He played in ''Muddy Waters: The Hoochie Coochie Man'' production in 1984.<ref name="Regional"/>  He played on albums for many blues artists, including [[Koko Taylor]], [[Eddie Taylor]], and [[Mud Morganfield]].  He appeared on stage with many blues greats, including [[Pinetop Perkins]], [[Willie "Big Eyes" Smith]], [[Louisiana Red]], [[Willie Dixon]], [[Magic Slim]] and [[Willie Kent]].<ref name="Something Else"/>

Hinds  has worked as a blues musician for more than five decades and he remains active on the Chicago blues scene with his own shows and often playing gigs with Eddie Taylor.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Stephenson|first=Mike|date=October 2009|title=Harmonica Hinds Finally|url=http://www.harmonicahinds.com/4.html|journal=Blues & Rhythm|publisher=|volume= |issue=233|pages= |doi= |accessdate=November 6, 2013}}</ref>  He continues to play a regular gig at [[Buddy Guy's Legends]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buddyguy.com/Calendar/|title=Buddy Guy's Legends Calendar|last1= |first1= |date= |website=buddyguy.com|publisher=Buddy Guy's Legends|accessdate=November 6, 2013}}</ref>  He performed at the 14th, 15th, 20th, 24th, 29th, and 30th [[Chicago Blues Festival]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/depts/dca/supp_info/chicagobluesfestival.html|title=Chicago Blues Festival - Performer Bios|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|year=2014|website=The City of Chicago's Official Site|publisher=City of Chicago|accessdate=May 19, 2014}}</ref> and he will perform at the upcoming 31st festival.

== Music and Performance Style ==

''[[Living Blues]]'' reviewer, Jim DeKoster, described Hinds first album "Finally" self-produced under [[CD Baby]] as "one of the most enjoyable albums in the classic Chicago blues style to come down the pike lately".<ref>{{cite journal|last=DeKoster|first=Jim|date=December 2008|title=Harmonica Hinds Finally|url=http://www.harmonicahinds.com/4.html|journal=Living Blues|publisher=Living Blues|volume=39.6|issue=198|pages= |doi= |accessdate=November 6, 2013}}</ref> When ''Blues Revue'' critic James Porter reviewed "Finally", he wrote that Hinds is "one of the most talented musicians on today's Chicago scene."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Porter|first=James|date=Feb–Mar 2009|title=Harmonica Hinds Finally|url=http://www.harmonicahinds.com/4.html|journal=Blues Revue|publisher=|volume= |issue=116|pages= |doi= |accessdate=November 6, 2013}}</ref> Critic Matthew Warnock's review of Hind's album "Anything if I Could" found that Hinds and his band understood the "key emotion that makes the blues the legendary music that it is" and brought "emotional intent behind each note."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Warnock|first=Matthew|date=|title=Harmonica Hinds Anything if I Could|url=http://www.harmonicahinds.com/4.html|accessdate=November 9, 2013}}</ref>
